III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Adult resident has been on an isolated pod due to their behavior
since August or September. Staff are providing this resident with
Percocet instead of prescribed medication.
Investigation This complaint was transferred to DCWL and assigned on
11/01/2023.
I spoke with Director via telephone on 11/01/2023, Director reported
Youth A had a court hearing today and during the hearing Youth A
said that Staff had given him Percocet. Youth A didn’t reference
staff’s name, date, or time when this occurred.
I interviewed Manager onsite on 11/02/2023. Manager reported
Youth A has been at the facility since May of 2023. Youth A was
moved from Pod H to Pod C in August due to being assaultive with
other youths and staff. She said Youth A has never reported staff
provided him Percocet. There are no incident reports involving staff
providing any youth with Percocet or any other drug.
I interviewed Clinical Case Manager onsite on 11/02/2023. Clinical
Case Manager reported Youth A had a psychiatric evaluation on
05/19/2023 and was diagnosed with Conduct Disorder Adolescent
Onset, ADHD, and Marijuana Abuse. Youth A’s father refused to sign
the psychiatric medication consent form, so when Youth A turned 18
last month, he signed the consent form and started his medication for
ADHD. She denied having any knowledge of staff providing Youth A
with Percocet. She said only supervisors dispense medication and
there is no record of Youth A being prescribe Percocet.
I interviewed Youth A onsite on 11/02/2023. Youth A is 18 years old
and has been at the facility for 6 months. He is currently on Pod C,
but was previously on Pod H. He was moved to Pod C in September.
He reported when he was on Pod C Staff 1 gave him Percocet.
Youth A could not recall the specific date or time when staff provided
him with Percocet, but said it happened sometime in August. He said
Staff 1 also wrote him love letters and would put the letters under his
bedroom door. When asked about the letters, Youth A reported he
gave the letters back to Staff 1. Youth A said he started taking
Adderall last month because his father had refused to sign the
consent form, so when he turned 18 he signed the consent form
himself. He has been getting his medication daily and the supervisor
dispenses his medication.
I interviewed Youth B onsite on 11/02/2023. Youth B has been at the
facility for four months and is placed on Pod H. He said Youth A was
placed on Pod H but was moved in September to another Pod. He
denied witnessing Staff A provide Youth A with any drugs. He said
only the supervisors dispense medication. He further denied
2

witnessing staff act or do anything inappropriate with the youths.
Youth B reported he is prescribed medication and is receiving his
medication daily. He expressed no concerns regarding any staff or
the facility.
I interviewed Youth C onsite on 11/02/2023. Youth C has been at the
facility for one year and is placed on Pod H. Youth C denied
witnessing staff provide any youths with drugs, love letters, or act
inappropriately with the youths. Youth C reported he is prescribed
medication and is getting his medication daily. He said the
supervisors dispense the medications. Youth C expressed no
concerns regarding Staff 1.
I interviewed Staff 1 onsite on 11/02/2023. Staff 1 is a Youth
Specialist and has been working at the facility for 6 months. Staff 1
typically works 2nd shift 2-10 pm. She has completed all training and
has no disciplinary reports. Staff 1 is familiar with Youth A from when
he was on Pod H. She adamantly denied providing Youth A with
drugs or writing him love letters. She was very surprised by the
allegations. Staff 1 said she is by the book and would never cross the
line with the youths. She always ensures she’s in front of the
cameras when interacting with the youths.
I interviewed Staff 2 onsite on 11/02/2023. Staff 2 is a Youth
Specialist and has been working at the facility for four months. Staff 2
typically works 3rd shift on Pod H. Staff 2 is familiar with Youth A.
Staff 2 has worked with Staff 1 and denied witnessing Staff 1 or any
other staff provide Youth A with medication. Staff 1 reported only the
supervisors dispense medication. She further said that if she
witnessed staff do anything inappropriate with the youths she would
immediately report to management.
I interviewed Supervisor onsite on 11/02/2023. Supervisor has been
working at the facility for 23 years. Supervisor said he heard that
Youth A said in court that staff gave him Percocet. Supervisor
reported he has no reports and has never witnessed or heard that
staff provide Youth A or any other youths with Percocet. Supervisor
reported he meets with staff every day before their shift starts and
reviews the previous shifts notes with staff, so staff are aware if
anything is going on with the youths. He has no reports or concerns
regarding Staff 1. He said Youth A has been very assaultive with
Staff and other youths and therefore he was moved in September to
a Pod C due to his behavior.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s treatment admission form dated 05/10/2023.
Reason for placement was carrying a concealed weapon.
3

• Youth A’s psychiatric evaluation dated 05/19/2023,
diagnostic information: Conduct disorder adolescent onset,
ADHD, explosive disorder, and marijuana abuse.
• Youth A’s Psychotropic medication consent form dated
05/19/2023, signed by Youth A on 10/08/2023.
• Youths Discipline Policy: continued negative behavior
includes possession of contraband, threatening the safety
of others/intimidating or bulling, consequence a loss of free
time (recreations privileges) or temporary return to level
one merit system.
• Employee training information reviewed for Staff 1 hire date
05/24/2023. Staff 1 had completed all new hire training.
Staff 1 has no disciplinary actions.
Analysis The facility is compliant with the rule as there is insufficient
evidence that Youth A was provided Percocet instead of his
prescribed medication. Staff and Youths were interviewed, who
reported not witnessing or being made aware of the allegations,
and the involved staff denied the allegations.
Youth A alleged during this investigation that Staff 1 wrote him
love letters, which Staff 1 denies, and Youth A could not produce.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
